qas.question: What was turned into a monument after the war?

answers.text: the main dome of Diaz's new senate hall

qas.question: Who was the man behind the modernization of Mexico City?
What was the overall design plan of Mexico City?
What was the main construction project in the Profirian/French style?

context: <a1_0>Diaz<a1_0/>'s plans called for the entire city to eventually be modernized or rebuilt in the <a3_0>Porfirian/French style<a3_0/> of the <a4_0>Colonia Roma<a4_0/>; but the Mexican Revolution began soon afterward and the plans never came to fruition, with many projects being left half-completed. One of the best examples of this is the Monument to <a2_0>the Mexican Revolution<a2_0/>. Originally the monument was to be <a0_0>the main dome of Diaz's new senate hall<a0_0/>, but when the revolution erupted only the dome of the senate hall and its supporting pillars were completed, this was subsequently seen as a symbol by many Mexicans that the Porfirian era was over once and for all and as such, it was turned into a monument to victory over Diaz.
